newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire rebels reject ceasefire, face resistance.
newsitem.headline: Zaire rebels reject ceasefire, face resistance.

text.p: Rebels battling toward the city of Kisangani have met stiff resistance but rebel leader Laurent Kabila has rejected calls for a truce, rebel sources and diplomats said on Friday.

Rebel radio said fighting between rebels and a motley army backed by Serb mercenaries and Rwandan Hutus was taking place somewhere on the road between Kisangani and Bafwasende 300 km (200 miles) to the northeast.
Diplomats in the Ugandan capital Kampala said Kabila met U.N. special envoy Mohamed Sahnoun in the northern Ugandan town of Gulu on Thursday but again rejected pleas for a ceasefire.

A regional military source said Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) were also advancing towards the lakeside town of Pweto in the mineral-rich Shaba province.
"We have been making probing attacks towards Kisangani and they have met some resistance which we cannot ignore," one rebel source in the eastern border town of Goma said.

In Zaire's capital Kinshasa panic ensued when soldiers seized 16 vehicles from a Belgian car company, reviving memories of nationwide army pillaging in 1991 and 1993. The government, conscious of public fears if the army's fortunes take a new turn for the worse, played down Thursday's incident.
A Zaire defence ministry spokesman said on Thursday Kisangani, the army's headquarters in the war zone, was quiet.

Military analysts say the combination of the Zairean army's better troops, Serb mercenaries and allied Rwandan Hutus might slow a rebel advance. The army, which has helicopter gunships, has sown mines around the city.

Diplomats in Kampala told Reuters by telephone that Kabila met Sahnoun in Gulu hosted by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, a regional power broker accused by Zaire of backing Kabila. But they said Kabila turned down Sahnoun's plea for a ceasefire.
"They met in Gulu in talks chaired by Museveni but Kabila bluntly refused to commit himself to a ceasefire of any kind," a diplomat said.
Tired and frightened Rwandan Hutu refugees have been limping into the town of Ubundu on the Zaire River upstream from Kisangani, with tales of the weak dying on the way.

While Kisangani has become a focal point for the struggle, guerrillas have slipped closer to vital mines in Shaba and Kasai. A regional military source said they were closing in on the town of Pweto on Lake Tanganyika in Shaba.
"We have detected major movements towards Pweto and the rebels are being aided by Kabila's popular support in that srea," the source said.
Rebel Voice of the People radio in Goma on Friday said Kabalo, a Zaire river town and railway junction close to the boundary between Shaba and Kasai, had fallen.
"Kisangani is very important, but it is only one step towards liberating the whole country," said rebel information commissioner Raphael Ngenda.

France called for a "security framework" for Zaire -- code words for a multinational force -- but diplomats said its European Union partners responded coolly. Kenya downgraded a planned March 19 mini-summit on Zaire to a preparatory meeting for a regional summit later.
Mobutu, who has ruled Africa's third largest country for 32 years, remained in France. He has spent most of his time in Europe since surgery for prostate cancer in August.
